The game itself is brilliant, unfortunately, Valve is distributing it in a broken, unplayable state for most windows Vista/7/8 users. This requires users to hack the install directory by renaming files, or to seek to resolve the problem by more convoluted and risky means.

It is of course BioWare's responsibility to fix this, but Valve is still selling it, and it's unacceptable that people feel the need to download anonymous executables off the internet in order to play a game they purchased.

If you feel like dealing with the head ache of trying to get this broken product to work, it's actually a very good game. It starts a little slow but you encounter lots of interesting characters, make lots of decisions that impact how things turn out, develop relationships with party members, get multiple endings, and can unlock a lot of cool powers. It's a very good game, it's like a pre-cursor to Mass Effect but JadeEmpireConfig.exe is broken and results in a Can't Find Steam error.

Oh the solution to the Can't Find Steam error? Simple

Make a backup of JadeEmpireLauncher.exe, create a copy of JadeEmpire.exe, and rename that copy to JadeEmpireLauncher.exe. Then run it in XP Compatibility Mode with Run as Administrator checked. For most people, this solves the problem. I'm sorry you had to look for a work around like this to make a game you spent money on playable.

One of the great Bioware RPGs up there with KOTOR and Dragon Age.  The biggest difference from their other games is that it takes place in the Eastern fantasy world of Jade Empire and character's fighting styles are inspired by martial arts practices and techniques. If you like Bioware RPGs and, or fantasy martial arts movies play this game.


To expand upon my previous review the game isn't as deep as Kotor may be, though simplified Jade Empire is still a great experience. The gameplay is more action based than other Bioware games, no strategic pause option, D&D rules, and such. You can use focus points to slow down time for an advantage or for certain styles. Each fighting style you gain can be leveled up and is like it's own weapon or feat. You'll most likely find yourself switching between two or three that work the best. The diologue and choices are as great as you'd expect from a Bioware game. The story is basic but leads up to a pretty good twist and the quests are great, hardly any felt like pointless fetch quests. Very enjoyable game that would make a great intro into RPGs or fans wanting more.

reviewText:
Despite the old graphics and occasional clunkiness, I think this is one of my newest favorite games. I was surprised by how well it stands up against the newer titles. If anything, the fact that this came before many of Bioware's other titles elevates it to a higher status for my regard.

The rundown:

Graphics:
This is an old game, and as such, will have old graphics. Textures aren't particularly high, faces can be a touch blobby, and clothing moves like awkward paper. I also found the cutscenes, while also marked with the usual low quality of the time, also had a strange film grain effect. This may be removable, but I never found it so pressing as to search for the option. Some of the cutscenes that involved content of a more gory/violent/disturbing nature did not appear so, though one's imagination can fill in the gaps (this may be a pro or con). Overall, I found the graphics acceptable for serving their task.

Audio:
I enjoyed the musical score, particularly the swells that appeared during the more intense moments in the game. I'll probably go see if I can hunt down the OST (EDIT: found the OST. It's still great). As for the dialog, I found the majority of major characters to have intriguing voices, and rarely felt the need to read the subtitles and skip when speaking with them. This was not always the case with the minor characters. I suspect the voices themselves are more than decent, but the lack of camera movement during a conversation could become a little stale (a flaw of the time, I would think).

Characters:
Unsurprisingly, this is where the high quality really shone through. Although there weren't as many opportunities as I would have liked to interact and speak with the companions (though to be fair, that's always my complaint), I found their backstories interesting and genuinely wished to know more about them throughout the game. I wouldn't have minded a few more side quests, or the ability to take more than one companion along, as I found myself taking the same two out. This just means further playthroughs are needed for the future.

Story:
What I liked about it was its seeming simplicity. It began in a rather straight forward manner, following some of the usual tropes. However, as the story progressed, I enjoyed seeing the new twists, and I wish to give particular commendation to some of the aspects in the ending. Unlike some of Bioware's more recent titles, I really wasn't certain if I'd made the 'right' choice (assuming there had been others - I've only played through once, following the Open Hand path). This ambiguity was very appreciated, and it's something I'm still thinking about. Some form of sequal would have really been fantastic, as I would have loved to see what my impact on the Jade Empire ultimately ended up being.

In short, despite the aging, I found the game to be extremely entertaining, and possibly a necessary staple to anyone curious about playing more Bioware games. I can definitely see myself replaying it. For information purposes, my playtime ended up being 23 hours.

One last note: The steam edition of Jade Empire had this issue where upon startup, it would tell it 'couldn't find steam' or some such drivel, and then promptly close. The fix was relatively easy. Exit steam entirely, and then run it as administrator, and then start Jade Empire. That should allow the configuration paths to form correctly (I believe that was where the issue lay, but I can't be certain. Regardless, the game worked normally for me then on out).

reviewText:
Introduction: Jade Empire won my heart several years ago, when I first played it on the original XBOX. For those of you who are familiar with BioWare products, it will come as no surprise that Jade Empire lives up to being a quality role-playing game. Clearly inspired by ancient Chinese mythology and folklore, this game is both alluring and enticing to players who can appreciate compelling storytelling combined with a refreshing cast of characters. While this particular title has a relatively simple design in comparison to many of BioWare's other creations, I would still encourage you to pick it up and check it out - Particularly if you are interested in refreshingly original environments, and parables.

Complications & Fixes:
While I recommend the game itself to anyone, I must ADVISE CAUTION TO THOSE SEEKING TO BUY IT ON STEAM. For some, the game will not operate smoothly (if at all) without downloading and installing an additional file. For those of you still needing help, there are many thread discussions regarding this error inside the community forums.

Alternatively, you can download and install the two files that I used (they worked for me) from:
https://anonfiles.com/file/2fd02e0d0446d3bcaa2c6b2d1fd85d8d

For reference, I believe this is the thread where I originally found the solution: http://steamcommunity.com/app/7110/discussions/0/864978835694348660

Story: Jade Empire follows an orphaned martial arts student, initially training under Master Li, who is unaware of his/her full potential... Or for that matter, the road that lies ahead of them. Little does the protagonist know that every step of the journey will be a test of character, which might or might not conflict with their martial skills. While facing other-worldly creatures, in a unique combat system, the student will grow to master his/her ability -  and only then can they face the dark power growing in the Jade Empire. This game does feature multiple endings based on the players path and decisions throughout the game.

Gameplay: The story is absolutely gripping, and is divided into 7 chapters, each featuring their own set of sub-quests.  Some quests are entirely optional, such as the option to form a romantic relationship with a NPC team member. I was honestly very impressed by some of the same-sex options, considering the release date of Jade Empire. This might actually be one of the first games that provided this option to the player. Throughout the game, the player will be able to make decisions for their character, which can in fact impact the ending. Furthermore, some of these decisions can also be used to influence your party members into following different paths as well.

There are two major philosophies that seem crucial to the game as well: The Way of the Open Palm, and the Way of the Closed Fist. These two opposing philosophies can easily compare to Yin and Yang (or the Dark Side and the Light Side from Star Wars). However, it is important to recognize that just because someone practices the Way of the Closed Fist does not actually mark them as evil... Likewise, a follower of the Open Palm is not automatically good either. Followers of the Open Palm believe that maintaining harmony is important, whereas the followers of the Closed Fist believe that one should become self-reliant. Whether or not an individual is good or evil boils down to the context surrounding the event, so Jade Empire strays from painting a black and white world. That in itself, is a noteworthy mention, all too rare in video games.

Another brilliant feature implemented in Jade Empire are the mini-games. I really really really enjoyed the Raiden-inspired Dragonfly mini-game. Seriously, just go check it out on YouTube or something, you could spend hours doing this alone. It is sooo fun!

Controls: I might have been lucky, but I didn't have any problems with the controls in this game. They were pretty straightforward, and the game is compatible with a XBOX360 controller. On the other hand, a friend of mine confirmed that Jade Empire is not compatible with the PS3 controller. Otherwise, the controls work perfectly fine for me, as to be expected. The combat system is a bit more complex than other games I've played, but the innovative style is addicting, I promise.

Graphics: The first thing to consider is that this game came out in 2005. As a result, the graphics might be considered outdated by many of you. However, I do not feel like the graphics are so outdated that they become a distraction. The visual aesthetic of the game may not be the best, but it's definitely not the worst.  I rather enjoy the art style of this game, however I cannot say that the graphics are the highlight of Jade Empire either... And yes, you will get stuck in weird camera angles until you reload it sometimes. There are glitches. Do not panic.

Sound: I think the language might be made up, but it sounds decent to me. The voice acting wasn't horribly obnoxious, and some of the music in this game is enjoyable to listen to. The audio surrounding this game meets par, as there isn't a lot to nit-pick.

Replay Value: Honestly, Jade Empire doesn't get old to me. I found the experience to be extremely enjoyable, and have since beaten the game several times since my first playthrough in 2005. Definitely worth playing twice!

reviewText:
When you think of Bioware, you usually either associate the company with either hilariously over the top fantasy romance, gritty bloody or D&D Fantasy and sci-fi moral guided RPG shoot from cover games.

But there was a time where they worked on a game with a very different setting and combat system. This is the game, and the settling is the sadly rarely used Chinese Fantasy. Jade Empire is a very different beast for what we now expect from modern Bioware games. Originally for the first Xbox and ported to the PC around 2007 back in the days where STEAM was also very different and oddly enough not well remembered.

I had fun playing Jade Empire. It was something new, despite the now dated graphics. It was something fresh despite the system limitations like being limited to a single companion and being one of the shorter Bioware games I have played. A good game always has a rock solid foundation. Very few games bother to cover China at all.  The combat system in this game is very unique and reminds me a lot of the more modern but quite different open world game Sleeping Dogs. You fight with WASD, general movement and using techniques (spells) that are fueled by a chi (mana) meter. This makes fighting a lot more fluid and interesting that the usual turn based stuff older RPG games are associated with and there is a simple wonder of going all Bruce Lee (and yes, one of the male main character models pretty much is a tribute to Bruce Lee) and kicking ♥♥♥ while staying mobile.

You aren't limited to your fists, there is the usual slightly bland array of metal weaponry and Chinese Magic style techniques some of which transform you into mythical fantasy beasts of the era. The companions themselves, whilst limited in combat are quite interesting like with all Bioware games. There is even the token 'Drunken Style Master' who helps boost you with buffs of well wine really. One of my personal favourite quests in the game is a much more interesting Arena quest that makes the younger Oblivion one seem hilariously bland and boring in comparism. Oh and John Cleese has a cameo too in which he plays an Arrogant ♥♥♥♥ of an Elizbethan Explorer who debates and fights you.

Sadly there are some flaws. Like I mentioned before the game is short, I played it one and off for an hour or two for the last few weeks and just shaved past the eighteen hour mark before completing it. Once you finish the Imperial City portion of the game pacing gets incredibly rushed and the scant quest based hub areas vanish completely. The storyline demands you to get it done and over with.

And the Gem system really could have done with some more thought. But these things are pretty minor. The most disturbing issue was the fact this game is one of the older titles that is broken due to STEAM constantly changing but I found a player bashed up fix in the STEAM community forums which was easily to install and get working in about a minute.

So final opinion really, if you are looking for something new and interesting in both setting and combat system RPG wise and don't mind the length and the age of the game you will enjoy Jade Empire. If you don't click with Martial Arts, Fantasy China or would rather have a more relaxed combat system I might suggest looking into amazingly well written Planescape Torment instead which is different enough to take a break from the more boring old school RPG games.

Worth picking up in a sale if it sparks your interest? Go ahead. Even outside the sale, the price is still pretty cheap and it will run like a charm now even on what we would consider old hardware in space year 2013/14.

reviewText:
Jade Empire could easily been seen as the first step for Bioware towards more simplistic and action based gameplay however it manages to avoid the scorn many felt towards the Mass Effect and Dragon Age series by providing a beautiful and inspired world, the writing is excellent and the characters are interesting.

You start the game off as a student at a martial arts academy. Things quickly change however as you are charged with saving the world and restoring balance in the world, pretty standard hero stuff really. You won't be on your great all important quest for long before some random peasant will ask you go save a cat from a tree however. Jade Empire is a game that loves procrastinating. Despite what should be a fairly urgent overall plot you will find yourself spending most of your time solving the problems of various little people around the world. Sometimes I'd even forget why I was doing all this in first place.

Jade Empire is gorgeous game. The graphics are stunning, the art style is impressive and the sounds and music work well together.

There is a certain open feeling to many of the quests and although this is only a disguise for the relatively linear progression you have throughout the game it does work well to keep you from feeling like you are completely on rails. The morality system, despite it's flaws, is probably one of the best ones ever concocted by Bioware and it hints at shades of grey quite often, particularly during the later stages of the game.

There is only really one major problem with Jade Empire and it is unfortunately a rather big one. The combat, the basic gameplay mechanic that the entire game is based around, is dreadfully dull.

The controls are fairly standard, light attack to deal damage, heavy attack to break blocks, your own blocking ability and an area effect strike in case you get swarmed. This is all very simple and not very interesting so what Bioware did in an attempt to make the combat more dynamic is provide you with a wide range of combat styles. Everything from familiarly named martial arts styles and weapons styles to magic and support styles and even transformation styles that morph you into various mythical creatures. The idea being that you need to switch between the different styles to maximize your combat potential. Unfortunately the entire execution of this is flawed and while you do need to change styles every blue moon to match enemy immunities there will only rarely be a need to do this in combat even on the highest level of difficulty.

Something that probably deserves a mention here is that Jade Empire is some very nice romance options and is quite possibly the only game to have a three-way romance option that didn't make me feel like puking.

All in all Jade Empire is a great game marred by some unfortunate design flaws. The world is beautiful and well crafted, the characters are interesting and engaging and Bioware's attempt at grey morality pays off surprisingly well. It's a game I'd happily recommend as it is a great play but the horrible combat unfortunately keeps it from getting that all time classic status that some seem to want to bestow upon it.

reviewText:
Jade Empire is without a doubt a very good game. It stands, however, very firmly, as a mid-point between Bioware's other landmark titles: Knights of the Old Republic and Mass Effect. It is very recognisable as a spiritual successor to the gameplay style of Knights of the Old Republic. On the other hand, you can see much that would go into Mass Effect being developed in Jade Empire. It says more than anything about Jade Empire that I could not write a paragraph in review without mentioning Bioware's other two excellent titles.

The characters and their development, the storyline, and quite frankly the world developed around them, simply doesn't live up to the heights generated by the other series mentioned herein. It perhaps helps with immersion that I was a Star Wars fan prior to playing Knights of the Old Republic; but Mass Effect's dramatic introduction of an entirely new universe was simply amazing and Jade Empire achieves nothing of the sort. It is a nice world, more densely populated than Knights of the Old Republic which makes it feel more immersive. But unfortunately it just does not stand out. It is not particularly memorable, and there is virtually no reason at all for the game to be open-world (when it does open up). If you are thorough, there is literally no reason to return to places you have visited in the past in Jade Empire, and that is rather unfortunate.

It is an aging game, so the graphics look a little dated at this point but you can still see that for their time they were quite pretty and it does not in any way impact the enjoyability of this title. The gameplay is also quite interesting, very fast-paced and there are a really wonderful array of fighting-styles that your character can learn. Slightly unfortunate, however, is the loss of the ability to play as other characters at will, which was a welcome feature included in Knights of the Old Republic.

All in all, this game is definitely worth looking into, especially for fans of Bioware's other excellent RPG titles. I have been rather critical in this review but it is only because Bioware has soared so much higher in other outings and with so much potential it is rather unfortunate that Jade Empire failed to achieve these expectations. Nonetheless, I still consider it one of the better RPG games I have played and would recommend giving it a shot. 8/10.

reviewText:
I bought Jade Empire when I found it in a bin for exactly 2 euros. Years later I bought it again on steam for another 2 euros. All I can say is: money well spent.

A lot of people will tell you that Jade Empire is Bioware's weakest game. When you measure any rpg up to Knights of the Old Republic or the original Mass Effect, chances are your perspective is going to be a bit disadvantageous for Jade Empire. This isn't star wars, and this certainly isn't mass effect, but it is a unique game that has all the makings of greatness.

I was bummed out in Knights of the Old Republic when I learned that the combat would be dictated by a D&D dice roll system. This is the kind of uncertainty I hate, the kind of unrefined gameplay that has absolutely no excuse to exist in the modern world. Jade Empire does away with that and gives you live action, direct, fist to face combat. It has aged like a biscuit though. It is tough, rigid, and unrefined by todays standards, but a step up from the roulette style gameplay from Knights. Combat is fun for while, but you'll quickly find yourself looking for ways to dispatch your foes as fast as possible. The game offers various options. Martial Arts allow you to attack your enemies with your bare knuckles and are generally effective against all enemies. Elemental Styles allow you to throw fire or ice (bending if you will) at the cost of chi. Various weapons are very effective against humans, but useless against spirits. Support styles allow you to set up your enemies for a finishing blow. And at a hefty chi price there are the transformation styles that allow your to morph into a being of pure awesome to obliterate your foe. There is plenty of choice for you to customise your style, and the game gives you a fine world to flaunt your skills.

Jade Empire is set in an oriental world. Full of references to Chinese, Japanese, Indian and Bhuddist mythology. If you have ever watched Avatar: the Last Airbender then you should get the idea. There aren't many games out there like this and Bioware has done a great job at crafting a world that looks the part. This is the nice thing about Jade Empire. You'll want to walk around and talk to people, help them (or ruin them, you know the drill). In the end though you'll still be after the same thing thing: Saving your master. You play a martial arts student, whose life is uprooted when a secret orderer invades your hometown and kidnaps your master. Que the hero music and get to it.

It is a shame Jade Empire has ages so poorly. The controls are fluent as a beached whale, and the character models are not always as polished as they could be. Still, its universe and setting are unique and if you like a decent RPG of westen make then do not hesitate to get this.

reviewText:
Short version: 76%Jade Empire is a solid BioWare adventure game with an enjoyable world and storyline, complemented by a frustrating combat system and stripped-down RPG mechanics. It probably won’t be your favourite action game of all time, but you definitely won’t regret playing it.

Long version:Jade Empire was created between the releases of two highly successful titles, which later overshadowed its existence, although not without reasons. At its core Jade Empire is nothing more than an attempt to recreate the success of Knights of the Old Republic with a new world based on a highly fictional version of early Imperial China. For the most part, it works well… just don’t expect much historical accuracy, especially on the shoot-em-up stages against the ancient Chinese Luftwaffe. Yes, you read this correctly.

An RPG usually is as good as its story, and the game won’t let you down in this regard. The plot is solid with a few good twists, the characters are memorable enough, and the mandatory romance subplot doesn’t feel as forced as in most games. But it’s hard not to notice that most quests are recycled from KotOR and Neverwinter Nights.

So, why is Jade Empire so obscure and forgotten? For two reasons. The first is the lack of actual role-playing elements, and the second being the combat system.
This was the first title where BioWare tried real-time player-controled action instead of random-based mechanics, and it’s not working too well. Fighting is just mindless button mashing and the hit detection is beyond horrendous; using hand-to-hand styles almost equals a death sentence. As you can imagine, this creates slight issues in a Kung Fu game.

Still, Jade Empire is a solid title, and highly recommended for those who like BioWare’s KotOR era. Set the difficulty to easy or medium to avoid the frustration over the combat system, and enjoy this little piece of uniqueness.

Look Closely for the Wires [3/5]
Those with a taste for Wuxia film will enjoy the authenticity of kicking martial butt through BioWare's rich world of (mostly) traditional Chinese fantasy, but this title is not without it's fair share of problems.

Nearly a decade after first release, it would be unrealistic to expect Jade Empire to represent the pinnacle of modern gaming experience; but if you get past the idea that 2005 brought only the meteoric rise of WoW - and a sequel to Battlefield - there is still plenty of entertainment to be had.

For the most part, bags of kung-pow action, offbeat one-liners and a colourful cast including John Cleese (yes, that John Cleese) distract from the game's more serious shortcomings; and although far from perfect, the story is strong enough to carry you most of the way with tongue planted firmly in cheek.

Combat is the clear focus for much of the title, and while hardcore gamers will probably be disappointed at the simplicity of A-buttoning your opponent(s) to a meaty pulp, there are a number of different fighting styles to switch between that help to keep the beatings somewhat fresh.

Taking nothing away from many other reviewers who could not get this title to run at all, somewhat surprisingly, Jade Empire fired up first time on my own modest system (Win7, 32 bit). Aside from one story-halting bug about half way through - fixed with a simple patch in my case - the title ran without hitch. Judging by other reviews however, I'd be wary of purchasing this title for a Windows 8 system.

Despite the age of this title, the occasional bug, and it's clunky, badly dated interface, I'd still recommend this to those with a love of Wuxia, or just looking for something a little different.

I loved this game when I played it on the original Xbox. Now I can't imagine why. It has possibly the worst combat and camera controls of any game I've ever played.

During combat, some button presses are often delayed by a few seconds. If you begin a combo and then try to dodge, it will complete the combo before dodging. Often so much time has passed between when you press the dodge button and when you actually dodge that you may no longer want to dodge. But you will. Oh yes, you will. The same goes for if any enemy is hitting you. You will wait for the enemy to finish THEIR combo before you dodge/attack. Basically, the combat is very stilted and unresponsive.

The camera is perhaps even worse. It's understandable given the age of the game and the hardware it was developed on that the camera would be somewhat limited. You can only tilt the camera up, not down, and the camera movement is very imprecise. That's all forgiveable. What is not forgiveable is how the camera behaves in combat. If you are fighting near a wall the camera will tilt at odd angles preventing you from seeing what is going on. This becomes especially annoying when you are fighting in a small room. reviewText: Jade Empire is an action roleplaying game which puts you in the role of a young martial artist on a quest to free his/her master from the grasp of the sinister order of the Lotus Assassins while slowly discovering the history and the machinations behind the titular Jade Empire. You can equip four of them at a time and learn to use them in tandem, manage their mana cost (or better said, chi or focus cost depending on the style used) and upgrade their stats carefully. reviewText:
Jade Empire is one of the greatest RPGs ever made, and I still cannot understand why it remains one of the most underrated ones.

It's easily Bioware's best work, which is an impressive accomplishment considering the excellence of Knights Of The Old Republic. I have very fond memories of playing this on my XBOX when it was first released, and then sadly giving the game away. Regardless of this version's totally unnecessary, asinine technical issues (which are fortunately easily resolved), this game is absolutely a must play.

It's somehow gotten even better over the years. What stood out to me when I was a kid was the mythological, epic story and the combat, and it remains nothing short of awesome.The engaging, intriguing characters bring the interesting plot to life, as well as grounding the more fantastical elements and making it personal. You cannot help but become emotionally invested in the world. Rich lore, side quests, and their corresponding items make it highly addicting.  At first glance, the combat may appear simplistic, but it controls smoothly and takes a while to truly master. The ability to use weapons and transform into intimidating demons is so great and never gets old. Once you become adept at switching between distinctive combat and support styles, fighting becomes an intricate and brutal dance. Multiple play throughs are a given, especially with the compelling morality system. The pretty graphics hold up surprisingly well, the soundtrack is breathtakingly beautiful, and Jade Empire will leave an impact on you that is sure to stay.

This is a game you should savour every moment of!

Jade Empire takes place in a mysterious and ancient empire inspired by East-asian cultures.
The game itself is a story-driven RPG which lets the player travel around the land with companions which you can converse with and learn all manner of back story and interesting knowledges from, while the story and and character development is just like most classical BioWare games, the gameplay itself is really funny, its real-time action kung fu with many different styles and with several mods the game's already deep combat system gets even better.

reviewText:
This is a borderline positive recommendation, for a number of reasons.

The story as a whole is good, but dissapointing. It is a very predictable story. You are a student to a great, but unknown master with a dark past that wants to keep you safe until the hand of destiny itself sets you on a path to restore balance in the empire. There is a twist that feels telegraphed and a bit of mystery surrounding one of the characters that gives itself away before you're even two hourse in, if you're paying attention. It is short, but in this case it's a good thing, as the story is so generic it would feel like wading through a pool of undried cement. At just about 25 hours, give or take, it paces itself rather well and is coherent, but for a game with conversation options, it's extremely linear, especially once you enter the fortress. The biggest let down is the conversations. Each conversation you are given a number of lines you can choose which amount to nothing unless it's an obvious good vs. evil type of choice. Each character you speak to reacts almost the same way and says the same things regardless of your answer, with some exceptions with the three romance options (two per gender). Also, every important character that you encounter more often than once will repeat themselves almost endlessly. In one conversation I had with the Water Dragon, she told me the same thing no less than seven times, to the detriment of my already dying brain.
The combat is, well, annoying. On one hand it's dynamic, keeping you involved in every fight, which is a good thing. On the other hand it's repetitive and even outright annoying. Your attacks have this bothersome ability of knocking back the enemy you are attacking just out of reach of your next attack, unless you pin them to the edge of the fight zone. Fast styles are almost hands down superior to any slower style because each attack interrupts your enemy (unless they are a massive enemy like the toad or elephant demons or the jade golems). The mechanics of each enemy, while interesting at first become a nuisance the further you go into the story, especially ghosts.
There is one mini game (thankfully) in the game, but I won't go into it as you can effectively skip all of it unless you want to finish a character's quest line. The other ones are useless, or next to.
The redeeming quality is the game's companion characters. For a short game they are rather one dimensional but interesting enough to last you the first half of the game after which you won't get anything more than remarks out of them, with the exception of your romance option. They will comment as you adventure and then when you all group up again will act like they were just then hearing about what was happening for the first time. However, they are colorful and fit very well within their one dimension, fleshing it out very well.

I understand that the review seems rather negative, but I rather enjoyed the game, with some glaring exceptions. Jade Empire is akin to that somewhat annoying dinner guest, who is pleasant enough company but you can't quite wait for them to leave, as much as you might wish to feel otherwise.

Overall this is a game that, in my opinion, desperately needs a sequel to redeem itself. I recommend it, but only barely. If you are looking to play an action game with a modicum of morality and interaction, this would fit quite well, but if you are looking for an actual rpg, this would not fit that bill

reviewText:
Jade Empire - An often over-looked gem

Thrown into a chaotic world full of different factions, you choose which path will you follow: the open palm or the closed fist. Before you uncover the truth about what goes on and what's your role in it, you will have to travel through cities, valleys, forests, swamps, caves and mountains, meeting interesting characters on every corner.

Even though the main focus of the game is story, the action-based combat doesn't lag behind and is enriched with different weapon tactics, various techniques and (eventually) transmorphing into mythical beings during fights. The only problem is, there doesn't seem to be enough time to really try these out, since by the time you collect most of them, the game is nearly over.

Jade Empire implements the aesthetic and mythology of the far east while building an intricate, believable world with great characters, mesmerizing environments and exciting quests. The ideas, characters and concepts woven into the game make it a beautiful place rich with detail. I want more!

reviewText:
Jade Empire is a RPG made by Bioware, studio behind Mass Effect; KOTOR and Dragon Age. You play as a kung fu student who goes after his master's kidnappers. Along the way happens a lot and you get meet lots of interesting characters.

Basically Jade Empire is what you expect from Bioware: lots of dialogue with your crew, simple battle mechanics and interesting lore and world. It takes its lore and world from chinese history and makes it its own. By today's standards graphics don't scare you away but they are nothing special.  Battle mechanics were almost merely one-button-smashing but there were also little bit strategic elements behind it.

In my opinion the main aspect in the game is the story. I found it starting up slowly with firt couple of hours but then it was hard not to play it 'till the ende by one sitting.

I recommend it with 9/10. Bulletproof Bioware quality.

reviewText: I never once looked forward to playing Jade Empire after the first time booting it.  Sure, it was serviceable enough of an RPG to keep me coming back until its conclusion but the game's flaws are too numerous and damaging to make it truely enjoyable or worthy of recommendation.  From its exposition-choked opening hours to its final moments which can be replayed quickly to achieve all possible endings, thus cheapening the experience, Jade Empire just feels weak and overwrought.  Dialogue is so ridiculously heavy and voice acting sometimes so poor that it had me angrily jamming my finger into the LMB repeatedly within ten minutes of starting the game.  Despite the game's insistence that I use various martial styles to deal with different combat situations, I rarely needed to do more than equip my longsword and spam the LMB in order to win fights.  Meh.  Jade Empire is clearly the result of a young Bioware biting off more than it can chew.  Add to this the fact that Bioware and Valve released a broken and unplayable version of this game onto Steam, requiring the consumer to do the necessary legwork to get it working and the result is a very resounding NO.

reviewText:
Jade Empire is a good game (though not a great one) that is worth playing if you are either:
A) A fan of Bioware games and want to know how they got from KOTOR to Dragon Age, or
B) Looking for an interesting RPG set in a faux-Chinese fantasy setting (as opposed to most RPGs, which are set in faux-European fantasy settings).

This is clearly a Bioware RPG.  The overall framework.  The way you gather and interact with your party.  The interface.  The dialogue choices and morality system.  All are very typical Bioware.  If you like those things, great.  If not, be warned.  If you've never played a Bioware game, then I'd probably recomed that you start with either Knights of the Old Republic, Dragon Age, or Mass Effect, all of which are better games (over all), than Jade Empire.

Jade Empire excels over other Bioware games, in my opinion, in three areas.  First, the combat system is above average for a Bioware RPG.  Similar to, but much smoother than, KOTOR.  Less tactical, but also less frustrating, than Dragon Age.  In fact, I think this is what they were going for with Dragon Age II, they just didn't get it quite right (given that Dragon Age II was rushed out the door, this is not surprising).  Combat is fun and fluid, and yet still tactically interesting.

The other area, is that the basic mini-game (a bullet hell, bomber-run style airplane game), works better than most Bioware mini-games.  Admittedly, this is a low bar.

Finally, the setting here is easily the most original that Bioware has ever done.  I really hope that they readdress it.  We don't see a lot of respectful, well-crafted, Asian-inspired fantasy settings in North American produced RPGs--and certainly not ones where all of the characters look Asian and have Asian-sounding names.  Yes, it's a hodge-podge of Chinese art, archetecture, and fantasy traditions--but Dragon Age is a hodge-podge of European-inspired art, archetecture, and fantasy traditions.  This is a great world, and I hope that they come back to it.

So what's the down side?

The minor complaint is that a few of the fights (less than 5) are wildly imbalanced.  As in, everything else will be trivially easy, and suddenly you will hit a fight that feels almost impossible.

The more serious complaint is that the game is really short, for a Bioware RPG.  My first playthrough of most Bioware RPGs takes between 40 and 70 hours.  My first playthrough of Jade Empire took less than 20 hours.  The game just felt TOO streamlined.  For example:
- Large sections of the Empire were mentioned, but the player was never allowed to visit them.
- Only 1 party member has a side quest.
- The romance (whichever option you take) feels very rushed, because of a general lack of interaction.
- One playthrough is not enough time to explore the corners of the combat system, but the storyline is too linear and the game too lacking in side-areas to explore, to encourage much replayability.

If anyone else had made Jade Empire, it would be a very good RPG.  Heck, it's still a very good RPG.  But for a Bioware game, it's a bit disapointing--which is sad, because it has a tremendous amount of potential.

Jade Empire is an essential Bioware roleplaying experience.  I prefer it to earlier offerings like Baldur's Gate because their creative team realized their own fantasy world from the ground up.  It sucessfully blends the tropes and conventions of classic wire flying films and asian folktales in what feels like a love letter to the genre.

As I write this the JE is almost ten years old and examining it reveals a prototype for the story driven/ action rpgs like DA and ME that would follow.  It is a sweeping tale that that places the player in the familiar role of the chosen one" whose actions will shape the course of the entire world as they chart their own personal destiny.  If this were a tabletop rpg I would hate this contrived convention but it works quite well in a single player video game.

My only complaint is that the PC version seems to respond more sluggishly to controller input than the console version that I played when it relased in 04."

reviewText:
Jade Empire is an immersive 3rd person game with an emphasis on story and martial arts - themed combat. JE was published and developed by BioWare, which many may recognize as the company under EA which is known to deliver on immersive, story rich games which often include innovative gameplay mechanics, such as the Mass Effect or Dragon Age series. Jade Empire is no exception, as the fighting is very rewarding and, surprisingly, does not get repetitive nearly as fast as you might expect it to. Different martial arts styles are very distinctive from one another, although certain martial arts and weapon styles outshine others, which means most players may opt out of changing styles due to the success they have with a certain one. Decision-making is a pivotal part of the game. The decisions you make will branch the story out to a certain extent, affect how characters react to you and also affect the ending too.

Jade Empire's story is long and immersive. You take the role of a student in a martial arts school lead by your mentor, Master Li. You can choose your character from a selection of different toons, either going with a pre-selected loadout (Starting styles and stats, like in many MMORPGs) or making your own loadout. Your own character isn't voice acted, which is a shame, but it's not that big of a deal.

Jade Empire is quite a long game and it takes you through various cities, villages and wildernesses throughout China. The game has a companion system, which lets you be accompanied by one character out of many others who you meet on your journey. You can switch out companions at nearly any time you wish, as they all follow you during your journey in the background. (Appearing in a camp when not selected). The story takes many turns and if you are into Chinese mythology or history, you will definitely enjoy Jade Empire. The game is a bit old, but it is not it's fault and I still warmly recommend it to anyone. It requires some patience from the player to listen to the narrative and get immersed in the story, as all BioWare games do anyway. In my opinion, the combat is very fun and rewarding, as for some bosses and enemies you really have to plan ahead and switch styles during the fight in order to survive.

The characters and the plot are what shine in the game the most for me. Some provide comic relief, some provide moral guidance for the decisions you must make during your journey, and some work to intrigue you and astonish you. My favorite character is hands down is Henpecked Hou, an awkward chef who acts as comic relief by complaining about how he will get beat up by his wife and who also provides a unique drunken martial style by throwing wine bottles at you during combat. A great guy indeed.

All in all, there is only one thing that I can think of that Jade Empire really, really needs. A sequel. Seriously. The game has a great story as long as you have the patience to play through it. The game is great and the main factor that makes it great is that there aren't many games like it out here in Steam.

reviewText: This is a great RPG from BioWare that fuses beat-em-up elements and the RPG-style gameplay you've seen from other BioWare titles. While it might feel a little clunky if you're coming off the heels of a Mass Effect or Dragon Age title, it still holds up well. It also happens to be the last game BioWare made before selling their souls to EA (who I guess never had any interest in this IP, given that it never did get a sequel), so if you want to see how things have changed it could certainly serve as a little case study.\n\nOne big problem is that the PC port (which was done by a company called LTI Grey Matter, which I can't find any info about online at all) is rather sloppy. Playing in widescreen stretches the UI out and I had some issues getting it to run at more than slideshow framerates on my GTX 960 (a perfectly capable card for a game like this). There's also some issues that seem to be particular to the Steam edition of the game, but you can find a few guides around to mess with the files necessary to fix that. The game has full controller support though, being that it was on the Xbox at first, so that's cool. I would actually recommend using a controller if possible, since the mouse camera movement is way too fast for me even on the lowest sensitivity, but maybe that's just me.

Recommendation-
This is a truly beautiful game, which presents a lovingly crafted and genuinely fascinating world, a host of fantastic characters and a great sense of freedom in terms of your actions in what is mostly a very polished package, and I happily recommend it to any PC gamer.

Rough Plot-
Jade Empire,  is loosely based on the legends of China - although Bioware has been careful to stress that it's not actually ancient China, which allows them to play around with all manner of elements ranging from geography to the inclusion of technology (often magic-powered) such as aircraft. Your character starts out as the star student of a martial arts school in a remote village, and in typical RPG style, you and your companions are quickly caught up in Much Bigger Things - to wit, the aforementioned ghouls, firebombings, and balance of heaven and earth - and sally forth to travel around the Jade Empire putting things right.

reviewText:
One thing I love about video games is their ability to make me feel special. In this world where most of us are - face it - pretty ordinary, it's great to be able to spend some time in a fictional place where you feel like you are truly making a difference. And in Jade Empire, this is not just a feeling that dawns on you when the credits start rolling. It's there from the very first minutes, and stays with you throughout the game.

Jade Empire is a typical, if slightly aged BioWare RPG. You can play the game in different ways depending on your preferences, and there are plenty of interesting characters to interact with. I wasn't too fond of a few companions initially, but they ended up growing on me. By the end of the game, I was happy to have all of them by my side.

On the downside, I ran into a bug that made the camera point at the floor a little more often than I'd like. This seemed to happen randomly and was pretty effective at breaking my immersion, but it could be fixed by saving and reloading.

This game is not as famous as most other BioWare RPGs (think SW:KOTOR, Mass Effect or Dragon Age), but it is interesting and unique in its own way, especially due to the Asian setting. Although not quite at the level of those blockbuster games, Jade Empire is more than worth your time.

reviewText:
A hidden gem by Bioware (creators of Mass Effect, Dragon Age, KOTOR)

Set in a fictional, steampunk representation of China, you are a promising student of a quiet training school of Martial Arts. When assassins attack, you are forced into a journey seeking answers, closure or revenge depending on how you handle the moral system.

The game also includes Bioware's trademark romances, which also include the capacity for gay and lesbian relationships (whilst the homosexual romances are censored, mods are available to remedy that)

Story is engaging, controls are simple to master, however the game is very glitchy and the voice talent - with few exceptions - is a bit cringeworthy.

It should be noted however that installing the game via steam will require a bit of tinkering to allow it to work on more recent operating systems, but help is available in the steam forums.

In spite of it's flaws, Jade Empire is grossly underplayed and still holds up to be a very entertaining and rewarding game.
I still hold out hope that a sequel will one day appear on the horizon as it holds ample franchise potential.

reviewText:
Jade Empire is an immersive 3rd person game with an emphasis on story and martial arts - themed combat. JE was published and developed by BioWare, which many may recognize as the company under EA which is known to deliver on immersive, story rich games which often include innovative gameplay mechanics, such as the Mass Effect or Dragon Age series. Jade Empire is no exception, as the fighting is very rewarding and, surprisingly, does not get repetitive nearly as fast as you might expect it to. Different martial arts styles are very distinctive from one another, although certain martial arts and weapon styles outshine others, which means most players may opt out of changing styles due to the success they have with a certain one. Decision-making is a pivotal part of the game. The decisions you make will branch the story out to a certain extent, affect how characters react to you and also affect the ending too.

Jade Empire's story is long and immersive. You take the role of a student in a martial arts school lead by your mentor, Master Li. You can choose your character from a selection of different toons, either going with a pre-selected loadout (Starting styles and stats, like in many MMORPGs) or making your own loadout. Your own character isn't voice acted, which is a shame, but it's not that big of a deal.

Jade Empire is quite a long game and it takes you through various cities, villages and wildernesses throughout China. The game has a companion system, which lets you be accompanied by one character out of many others who you meet on your journey. You can switch out companions at nearly any time you wish, as they all follow you during your journey in the background. (Appearing in a camp when not selected). The story takes many turns and if you are into Chinese mythology or history, you will definitely enjoy Jade Empire. The game is a bit old, but it is not it's fault and I still warmly recommend it to anyone. It requires some patience from the player to listen to the narrative and get immersed in the story, as all BioWare games do anyway. In my opinion, the combat is very fun and rewarding, as for some bosses and enemies you really have to plan ahead and switch styles during the fight in order to survive.

The characters and the plot are what shine in the game the most for me. Some provide comic relief, some provide moral guidance for the decisions you must make during your journey, and some work to intrigue you and astonish you. My favorite character is hands down is Henpecked Hou, an awkward chef who acts as comic relief by complaining about how he will get beat up by his wife and who also provides a unique drunken martial style by throwing wine bottles at you during combat. A great guy indeed.

All in all, there is only one thing that I can think of that Jade Empire really, really needs. A sequel. Seriously. The game has a great story as long as you have the patience to play through it. The game is great and the main factor that makes it great is that there aren't many games like it out here in Steam.

reviewText:
Jade Empire is a good game (though not a great one) that is worth playing if you are either:
A) A fan of Bioware games and want to know how they got from KOTOR to Dragon Age, or
B) Looking for an interesting RPG set in a faux-Chinese fantasy setting (as opposed to most RPGs, which are set in faux-European fantasy settings).

This is clearly a Bioware RPG.  The overall framework.  The way you gather and interact with your party.  The interface.  The dialogue choices and morality system.  All are very typical Bioware.  If you like those things, great.  If not, be warned.  If you've never played a Bioware game, then I'd probably recomed that you start with either Knights of the Old Republic, Dragon Age, or Mass Effect, all of which are better games (over all), than Jade Empire.

Jade Empire excels over other Bioware games, in my opinion, in three areas.  First, the combat system is above average for a Bioware RPG.  Similar to, but much smoother than, KOTOR.  Less tactical, but also less frustrating, than Dragon Age.  In fact, I think this is what they were going for with Dragon Age II, they just didn't get it quite right (given that Dragon Age II was rushed out the door, this is not surprising).  Combat is fun and fluid, and yet still tactically interesting.

The other area, is that the basic mini-game (a bullet hell, bomber-run style airplane game), works better than most Bioware mini-games.  Admittedly, this is a low bar.

Finally, the setting here is easily the most original that Bioware has ever done.  I really hope that they readdress it.  We don't see a lot of respectful, well-crafted, Asian-inspired fantasy settings in North American produced RPGs--and certainly not ones where all of the characters look Asian and have Asian-sounding names.  Yes, it's a hodge-podge of Chinese art, archetecture, and fantasy traditions--but Dragon Age is a hodge-podge of European-inspired art, archetecture, and fantasy traditions.  This is a great world, and I hope that they come back to it.

So what's the down side?

The minor complaint is that a few of the fights (less than 5) are wildly imbalanced.  As in, everything else will be trivially easy, and suddenly you will hit a fight that feels almost impossible.

The more serious complaint is that the game is really short, for a Bioware RPG.  My first playthrough of most Bioware RPGs takes between 40 and 70 hours.  My first playthrough of Jade Empire took less than 20 hours.  The game just felt TOO streamlined.  For example:
- Large sections of the Empire were mentioned, but the player was never allowed to visit them.
- Only 1 party member has a side quest.
- The romance (whichever option you take) feels very rushed, because of a general lack of interaction.
- One playthrough is not enough time to explore the corners of the combat system, but the storyline is too linear and the game too lacking in side-areas to explore, to encourage much replayability.

If anyone else had made Jade Empire, it would be a very good RPG.  Heck, it's still a very good RPG.  But for a Bioware game, it's a bit disapointing--which is sad, because it has a tremendous amount of potential.

One thing I love about video games is their ability to make me feel special. In this world where most of us are - face it - pretty ordinary, it's great to be able to spend some time in a fictional place where you feel like you are truly making a difference. And in Jade Empire, this is not just a feeling that dawns on you when the credits start rolling. It's there from the very first minutes, and stays with you throughout the game.

This game is not as famous as most other BioWare RPGs (think SW:KOTOR, Mass Effect or Dragon Age), but it is interesting and unique in its own way, especially due to the Asian setting. Although not quite at the level of those blockbuster games, Jade Empire is more than worth your time.

reviewText:
Okay so final thoughts on the game. It still has that compatibility bug that requires downloading a patch launcher and config.exe that is available in the forums but the game itself is enjoyable. The special edition adds only minor things  compared to the original (mostly graphical and AI improvements but also some style upgrades and a new higher difficulty) which is disappointing as it still means the main quest and all side quests can be finished in under 20 hours.

Combat is fun and smooth though the transformation styles are still incredibly OP when maxed out and the martial styles can feel weak late game unless you use chi attacks. There are occassional graphical errors and they can require reloading the game, going into another area, or going into combat to fix. The amount of lore explored in the game is impressive and some of it will play a major role in the main story.

Going down the Closed Fist path can lead the player on a much darker course than the Dark Side from their previous game KoToR but the game does suffer from the fact that a major choice made at the end will decide whether you get the Open Palm or Closed Fist ending (props to Bioware for a 3rd choice to let the antagonist win) no matter your 'alignment' before this choice, though there are multiple endings for the party NPCs. There is good characterization and interaction with and between the party's NPCs and a late game choice can add a serious twist to your relationship with them. I'd say Bioware built upon this in their development of their next game Mass Effect.

Overall an excellent game, if a bit short, and a recommended one if you don't have it or have never played it before. Why a sequel has never been produced is baffling though likely due to Bioware focusing so heavily on the Mass Effect and Dragon Age series, and on Star Wars: The Old Republic.

reviewText:
This game is one of Bioware's earlier RPGs before Mass Effect and Dragon Age modern fame.  Like a lot of developers, all their works share similar themes.  Good characterization, good humor, binary good / evil (although in this case its styled differently), good voice acting, etc.  The setting and music are characterization are all good and very well enjoyable, and quite amusing at times.  Bioware is very good at that, and I applaud them.

The problem with the game is that the actual -game- portion is just not very fun.  The combat is downright awful because there is no balance or flow.  Most enemies could be button-mashed to death, and those that can't usually have some sort of rediculous advantage over the player such as no hitstun, extremely high damage, or extremely high health.  There are two types of MP, one for magic + healing and the other for weapons + bullet time... but considering that there is no other way to restore your health aside from generous cutscenes I can't see magic being useful.  Leveling up a weapon style makes it use almost no MP but bullet time drains MP like pouring water out of a cup.  Animations are VERY clunky and often uncancelable, and each style only has one combo and one guardbreak attack.  Controlling your character in fights is a pain because being locked on to an enemy makes you extremely slow, and free camera makes it impossible to hit enemies reliably.

Levelling up gives points to spend in combat styles and other points to spend on stats, but there's no way to really know if you're going to get a good style later down the line and spent points are permanent.  Its a pitfall of RPGs, not knowing how well-spent your resources are because of a lack of transparency in the system.  Luckily stats are more easily corrected as you can swap equipment to boost the little used conversation stats and your primary stats, but nothing boosts your damage or defense directly.

There are scant few puzzles in the game that really only pad or are otherwise obnoxious (get out a pen and paper because you'll need to memorize), and a seemingly pointless Galaga minigame that occurs often and produces no non-Galage related rewards.

The game runs fine on Win7 / HD6850 / 3.2GHz * 6 / 8gb RAM system.  Its was made for the original XBOX and it shows, but the game controls perfectly fine on PC as a port even in the few fixed camera scenes.

I'd say pass on the game unless you like Bioware titles or the asian setting.  The combat in the game holds the whole package back far too much to be a robust title.  It's not worth suffering through for the story, which is only okay, even if well presented.

reviewText:
This is the game that got me into Bioware games. I have very fond memories playing this countless times on my original Xbox. The main story is well writen and the world beautiful. The characters and the majority of the side quests are interesting.  If you are a John Cleese fan, he does have a cameo in the game in one of the side quests. It still looks great on my computer as it did when I first played it on my original Xbox.

I personaly feel, combat itself is what hurts it however. Each of the fighting styles has one heavy attack and one light attack with the same blocking animation, with no real combos. This can make the combat feel boring at times if you are only using one or two fighting styles. You will be wanting to increase the number of fighting styles and hotkeying them so it does not feel as repetitive.

I do prefer this version on my PC since the load times are not as bad as the version on my Xbox. However this copy took me a while to get it to work on my computer. I had to go threw countless troubleshooting and work arounds but eventualy I did get it to work.

If you are a Bioware fan and enjoy RPG's I can easily recommend this game even though I went threw hell trying to get it to work.  It is a shame that this game is considered to be a commercial flop since I feel that it should have done better when it first came out.
